This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

PALESTINE - SYRIA LINE.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).
RED SEA LINE.

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakin direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. for a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suakin, Massowah, Hodeidah, Aden. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: THE NATIONAL HOTEL, Cairo
div.p: One of the finest and most up-to-date Hotels in the Metropolis. Situated in Sharia Soliman Pasha, the very centre of the healthiest and most fashionable quarter. Stands in its own grounds with garden and lawn tennis grounds at back. Over 350 rooms and 5 saloons. Magnificent salle à manger. Handsome covered promenade verandah, 80 yards long. Highest class cuisine, electric light throughout, and lifts. English comforts. Rooms and apartments at prices to suit everyone. For further particulars apply to GENERAL MANAGER, Cairo.

Sulphur Bath Establishment.- Sulphur water stronger than any in Europe. Eight European Masseurs and Masseuses. Every modern improvement.

div.head: THE HELLENIC CASE
div.p: M. Athos Romanos, the well-known Greek politician and ex-Minister for Foreign Affairs in the previous Theotokis Cabinet, has just published a well-written pamphlet on the persecution of his countrymen by the Bulgarians. As the Greeks are being continually censured for their conduct to the Bulgarians in Macedonia, it is only fair that it should be realised that there is another side of the question.

M. Romanos has wisely accompanied his statements with photographs showing the havoc wrought by the Bulgarians in the Greek Club and the Greek School at Philippopolis, the latter founded by M. Maraslis, of Odense, the well-known Greek philanthropist and patriot, and the almost complete destruction of the Hellenic quarter of Anchialos, on the Black Sen. It is noticeable, as one of these photographs demonstrates, that the conflagration, which destroyed nine hundred Greek houses and shops, stopped, as if by miracle, before the walls of the Bulgarian Church - miracle worthy of the Middle Ages, which was doubtless intended to point the moral that walvation of | life and property is to be found by those who follow the Bulgarian Exarch rather than by the adherents of the Ecumenical Patriarch. The Bulgarians say that the fault lay with the Greeks, who provoked reprisals by their resistance. It would have been greatly to the discredit of the latter if they had not done so. Anchialos contained six thousand Greeks, and when they saw one of their compatriots fall, pierced by a Bulgarian bullet, they naturally fired on his murderers. Not having many weapons they could not beat off the Bulgarian bands, and the fire ere long rendered further resistance impossible,

M. Romanos complains bitterly that the Bulgarian Government has not restored to his fellow-countrymen their churches and schools. The Bulgarian lion, he wys waves over the Marasli school at Philippopolis, which has been proclaimed State property, and no less than sixty-six Greek schools, formerly attended by eight thousand pupils, have been closed by the application of a clause in the Bulgarian Education Act of 1891 which has hitherto been a dead letter. M. Romanos points out that this action constitutes an infringement of the religious liberty guaranteed to the Greeks of Bulgaria by the Berlin Treaty and by the Organic Statute of Eastern Rumelia (now South Bulgaria). He might have added, that complete religious toleration exists in Greece, whether the creed concerned be that of the Roman Catholics of the Cyclades and the Ionian Islands or that of the few Mussulmans who have remained in Thessaly since its retrocession to Greece in 1898. The very first Article of the Greek Constitution, while forbidding proselytism, guarantees complete religious liberty, and this is not a mere rhetorical flourish of the Parliamentary draughtsman, but fact The State subsidies the Turkish muftis of Thessaly, and Roman Catholics and Jews have their own religious instruction in the public elementary schools.

It is no doubt, unfortunate that the Eastern Christians should hate each other so cordially, but they have always done so, and in that res peet they differ only in degree from the more civilised Western Christians Europe, however, is entitled to know that the fault is not all on one side and that all Bulgarians are not angels and all Greeks are not the opposite. Finlay, himself • Philhellene, could laugh during the War of Independence at the extravagances of Philhellenism. But people are now in danger of going to the opposite extreme that of thinking that the Greeks can do nothing right because they have, like even the youngest of us, made some mistakes.

div.head: BIG HAUL OF HASHISH,
div.p: £5,000 WORTH SEIZED.
ENGLISH RESIDENTS INTREPIDITY

Very important seizures of hashish were made at Ramleh on Monday and yesterday, which illustrate in a remarkable manner how adept the servants of some of the most respectable fans in Berkeley are in running bashish. The house of Mr. HC. Parkinson, the general manager of the Khedivial Mail Steamship Company, is right on the lift at Berkeley, and is protected from the inroads of the seas by an almost perpendicular sea wall. Access to the house from the beach is obtained by some steps on the wall. The Coastguard Administration's patrol cannot get to the coast at this point as the approaches to the East and West are cloned by two walls to the end of the cliff.

Early on Monday morning, at about 1 o'clock, Mr. Parkinson was aroused from his slumbers by peculiar thudding noise. He went round the house and was surprised to find light in his kitchen. He entered and found his suffrage engaged in making tea. The suffrage said that it was bad to be out, and, feeling cold, thought he would make some tea. This explanation did not, however, not count for the strange noise, so Mr. Parkinson ordered the man to go out and see if anybody was moving about in the er d'osure. The man went off and came back soon afterwards declaring that he could not find a soul outside, and that all was quiet.

Mr. Parkinson then went to bed again, but soon afterwards he again heard the mysterious thud, thud, thud, jost outside his house. Rounded with people walking in the yard of his horse dragging huge weights with them, and they distinctly noted the footfalls. He determined to probe the mystery to its depths and, arming himself with a loaded revolver, he went himself to ascertain the truth. It was pitch dark night, and nothing could be distinguished. Batas be was moving round and nearly stumbled over a big sack. He at once goers what game was being played and recognised that hasbieb was being landed. He went to his telephone and rang the Coast guard station at Ramelb, which is only about five hundred metres off. Help was at once sent and eighteen sacks of bashish were found round about the enclosure. One of the sacks was brought to light hidden in the room of Mr. Parkinson's suffragette.

The importance of this seizure may be recognised when it is known that the selling price of such an amount of hashish would be between L.E. 4,500 and L.E. 5,000, for the sacks contained twelve hundred kilo over a ton's weight

The suffrage was handed over by Mr. Parkinson to the Coast Guard, who took him into custody. Evidently the sacks of hashish had been floated in from a boat lying in the offing, as it is impossible to eftaota landing there except on moonlight night. The smugglers must have been very somerous as it would require at least ten men to marry off seob a large haal. When Mr. Parkinson was ringing up the telephone to the Coast Guard he heard the sound of the whole carriage driving rapidly away. This no doubt contained some of the smugglers.

Yesterday, when the coast guard were taking the suffrage to the Customs Administration Commission in order to be brought to trial, he said that he had some news to tell them, and he volunteered the information that if they I would look in the stable of the house adjoining Mr. Parkinson's, which is inhabited by Mr. Borohgrevink, the Procureur General of the Mixed Tribunals, they would find another tres tre trove of ashish. Subsequently, on a search being made, tourteen sacks were found hidden under the tibia in Mri. Borchgrevink's stable. His native coachman, who has been Gitteen years in his service, is about to be taken into custody. Both be and Mr. Parkinson's suffrage were most respectable servants. The latter was in the service of Major Mackenzie Pendrell for some time. Evidently the servants in houses by the sea at Ramleh are corrupted by the smugglers, who are quite able to offer Snormons bribes of hundreds of pounds for 9-operation.

Mr. Parkinson and his next-door neighbour, Mr. C.A.H. Alderson, have now given the Coast Guard Administration permission to station a guard within their enclosures, as this part of the coast is evidently convenient pace for running hashish I To show how carefully laid were the sung Iglars plans on this occasion, we must mention that Mr. Parkinson on Sunday night did not notice his fax terrier and only saw it again at about 7 o'clock next morning, when it oame home collarless and lame. It had been removed the day before and tied up some way off. flag the dog been in the bonae, it would have at once given the salary,

Two hours after the discovery of the hashish "the Coastguards in the Eastern Harbour were arrested . suspicious looking native craft, which | welt strongly of hs bish and bad on board an empty portmanteau, which also had the same odont. It bore a Greek label. The boat and crew were taken into custody and the latter are to be brought before the Custom Commission.

It is understood that the bashish found at Bulkeley was brought over from Greece in sobooner, which was met off Aboukir by vative boat There is no doubt that this great se zute of £5,000 worth of ba hsh is entirely due to the plook of Mr. Parkinson, who ventured out alone at a time when there must have been at least ten smugglers in the bus compound, all of them desperate at the prospect of losing such a valuable cargo.

div.head:
THE OASES
GOVERNMENT MEASURES
div.p: The Egyptian Government has decided to shortly appoint Mr. R. & Patterror, of the Inspectorate of the Ministry of Finance, Inspector of the four one of Khraab. Dakhleb, Babariah, and Paratra. This appointment of Mr. Patterson will be for two years and special powers will appear to that official.

The Ministry of Finance has decided to carry out a thorough survey of all the land Down under cultivation or which will be brought under cultivation in the near future in these four onres, which have never been surveyed before except geologically. In the Oases of Khargeh band Dakhleh the basis of taxation in water instead of land, elsewhere in Egypt. This survey will be undertaken with a view to eventually changing the basis o as to bring the principle of taxation prevailing in there ones in harmony with that in vogue throughout the rest of Egypt.
Mr. Buckley, of the Irrigation Department, who is at present employed at the Ghizeh Pumping Station, will leave shortly for Kharge to enquire into questions connected with the water supply.

div.head: KENEH-ASSOUAN RAILWAY.
div.p: The Egyptian Railway Administration is making great improvements on the Keneb Assouan lino. A considerable outlay on this section of the Upper Egypt line is fully justified, as the traffic berea Luxor sod Asso Can be recently greatly increased. lo fact, owing to this somewhat unexpected development of the passenger trofas, taken in connection with the heavy goods traffic and the large quantity of material transported for the works in progress on the line, the resources of the railway have been severely strained. The bomber of passengers booked at Ampuan alone is about double the number dealt with at Port Said. To meet the development of the traffic now can have been pet on between Luxor and Arouse and a regular dining car is also to be put on. So far as the road is concerned, great improvements are to be made.

div.head: REVOLUTIONARY CAIRO:
div.p: We have been favoured by the Ottoman Constitutional League, lately founded at Cairo, with copies of its statuten, which are printed in French, Tarkish, Arabie, and Armenian. Its programme consists of ten articles, defining its objects, which a . to re establish, by all means legitimate, constitutional government in Turkey, with a responsible Ministry. All Ottoman subjects, irrespective of race and creed, may form part of the league, which will have its headquarters for the time being at Cairo, will appoint' sab committees, and direct their plan of action. The pamphlet winds up with an appeal to patriotism in behalf of the liberation of millions of unfortunates.

div.head: WORKMEN'S HOUSES.
div.p: MUNICIPALITY'S REPLY TO COMMISSION

As our readers are aware, a letter which was something of the nature of an ultimatum, as addressed by the Popular Houses Commission to the Alexandria Municipality on the 11th inst, calling for some statement as to the progress of the scheme, placed before the authorities, failing which the Commission threatened to resign in a body.

An official answer is now for booming ln a letter dated the 14th ist to Cavaliere Ronel, president of the com minion, the Administrator of the Municipality, Mr. W. P. Chata way, acknowledges receipt of the former's letter, which he promises to com to unioa'e to the Delegation, and adds that, from information received, be is able to state that the Government has completed its study of the proposal relative to the land necessary for the work men's dwellings, and that definite reply will be given in a few days.
THE RECENT EARTHQUAKE

The earthquake which wrought aneh awful buvoo in the West Indies and obliterated Kingston on Monday last, .wms fault in Egypt on the day. Some people declare that they experienced tremulous sensation as of an earthquake. The fact that on Monday evening the election wires at Ramleh, Cairo, and Jealous tapped and the light went out is presumed to have some connection with the earthquake.
ZAGAZIG STREET LIGHTING.

A difference has arisen between the Ministry of Public Works and of the Interior, on the one side, and the Ligasig Municipality on the other. It appears that on June 11, 1906, the Municipality beld meeting to discuss the question of lighting the streets of the towa with gas or electricity, and finally appointed committee of four of its members, including the sab moudir, to visit several towns and study the merits and demerits of the various systems. After a study of their comparative merite the committee drew up a report in favour of the adoption of electric lighting. The Ministry of Public Works had other views. Mr. Perry. Under Secretary of State for Towns and Buildings, in note addressed to Sir W. Garstin, Recommended the adoption of the Mansfield gas system. The Municipality, however, read the report sud voted for eleo tricity, and there the matter resta · In our opinion, the Zaganigians (or should - write Zgarie Pea) might be left to choose for themselves aplex their proposal is likely to involve them in very high expenditure. After all, if are to love municipalities in the provincial towns they should not be, a to speak, spoon ted by the central authorities, uples invalided by their financial) excesses.
KHARTOUM'S STREETS.

It is esmaestly hoped that the Government will increase the money devoted to the main tenets of the Khartoum streets. The increase in the traffic, bob wheeled and otherwise, has been enormous of late and consequently the strain on the roads, particularly the most frequented thoroughfare has been such a to leave them in a very bad condition unless they are properly looked after.

We are aware of the financial difficulties which stand in the way of lavish expenditure on the roads; and until the water works are an accomplished fact, it will not be easy to keep the roads in good condition. Besides, the Government has hundreds of projects for the development of the country for snobs of which large amounts of money are urgently required. But in voicing the public opinion on this matter we hope that some means may be found to give the Capital of the Badan better streets so as to keep pace with the remarkable development of the town. ("Sudan Times")

div.head:
MR. ROBERTSON, M.P.
VISIT TO ALEXANDRIA MUSEUM
div.p: Mr. J. M. Robertson, M.P. paid visit to the Alexandria Museum yesterday. He was very pleased with the progress that the Museum is making and expressed his satisfaction to Professor Breccia, the curator of the Museum. H. displayed keen interest in many of the srebæological tronenres which be noticed. Professor Brescis personally sendast od Mr. Robertson over the building and we thanked that gentleman for his attention.
Mr. Robertson left Alexandria today for Cairo by the midday express.

"Al Watan," the Coptie organ, in ite in retorting portrait gallery of the friends and supporters of Mustapha Pasha Komel, devotes ito ninth character sketob to Mr. Robertson, whom it deals with as follow -

We now deal with Mr. John Robertson, M.P. He has clothed himself in the cast offs of M. Delancey, merely sewing on Yew Union Jacks. Consequently be has become the friend of our enthusiasts and their saviour from the laws of the Lion in Occupation. Had he thought fit to visit the Best Indies instead of hoisting his flag on the banks of the Nile he would have only foord semis. Por the(Moslem) Nationalista of lodia have decided (vide their recent manifesto) that Begland is their friend and their protector and that their daty is to give proote of their loyalty. But our patriotard has not yet capitulated.

We remarked that Robertson is the friend of certain enthusiasts; be has left for the provinces by express invitation of some of our "bona bourgeois.Bat does the publio remember the renowned Dolo Polo and his protestations of friendship, the immense banqueta offered him, and all the money squandered on his visit to Bcrypt 1 None the lease be sold the country to Bagland, he forgot us all, and has apparently also forgotten his own past policy. We may add that he was always in pain to help himself to all that came his way. One day we shall doubtless bay a third De lonoke who will give petition of this someday German Delono-who knows There is a good opening for him and his likes as long as there exist with lens individual with impossible dreams and the fixed idea that Tonal departs from M. P. os sway the politician of a great nation. Yes, German Delonole and Teatos Robertson are possible. div.head: ZIZINIA THEATRE
div.p: "LA DANNAZIONE DI FAUST."

"La Dannazione di Paust" was given again last night, in a performance which reflected the greatest oredit on management. The choran were again, for the most part, in excellent tone, and the stadenta sang their big Pague at the end of Act II. in most spirited. This was indeed a number which might well have been ignored rather than the somewhat sugary cereal flight of Silfide later on. Mefisto fole was once more excellent, and between Boito and Berlier he must experience no little difficulty in relapsing into the prose of lite above ground. But we cannot deny that, with all these merits, the piece shield is our opinion be played a Berlios wrote it, that is, me concerto for orchestra and chords. The music is so impressive and opening that given a full accompanying programac it is baid to see how soonary and eating brightens the impression. It is in the movie that we would like to rivet our attention. We do not oare to have it incidental, even to the greatest triumphs of stage management: for it comes, after Beito, overwhelming with its grent genius the work of that patient hack.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL CLUB DANCE.
div.p: The dance given last night by the members of the Khedivial Club was a very great success. Notwithstanding the bad weather that prevailed there were 400 guests present. It is needless to say that the olav's preemies looked their best, profusely decorated as they were with the choicest plants and brilliantly lit op with altitude of electrie lampe. By eleven o'clock the large reading room, which is used as a ball-room, was full, and doing bad began. The scene presented was charming in the extreme. The ladies were most bands only be owned, the light colours of their beautiful tulettes contracting with the dark green opi form of the 60tbR flash and the red costs of the Dublin Fusiliers, the officers of both their regiments being present in fall foron. It is quite impossible to give the names of thore present ; but we noticed H. B. the Governor of Alexandria, the officers of the Army of Occupation, the Consular Cerpe, judges, Government officials, and the elite of the English and foreign society.

A most excellent rapper, for which the elub is renowned, was served to over 10 guests, after which the cotillon began. Mrs. Rees and Miss Holland, assisted by Mr. Sidney Wilkio. son and Mr. Reer, led this dance, and it was due to their efforts that it proved huge Success. The presents given away were profese, and in some cases of a very rich nature. The greatest prison is due to the ladies we have mentioned, who took the atmoet pains and were indefatigable in their attentions to every great. Such was their agreement that the cotillion, which began at 1 o'clock, did not end until four a.m.
Before ending our report of this most successful dance, we must mention that all the members of the club did their best to entertain their guests, and were ably supported by their active secretary.

KINGSTON DESTROYED BY EARTHQUAKE.
MUCH LOSS OF LIFE.
NEW YORK, January 15.
According to telegraphic advice received here, the city of Kingston (Jamaica) has been destroyed by an earthquake. There has been much loss of life. The direct telegraph system has been interrupted.
(Reuter)

Kingston, the capital of Jamaica, stood on the north side of a land-locked harbour, the boat in the island, and, for its size, one of the best in the world. Its population was about 48,000. It was founded in 1693-1703, after the Neighbouring town of Port Royal had been destroyed by an earthquake. From this place, afterwards rebuilt, Kingston was a distant 6 miles, the breadth of its noble heaven ; while with Spanish Town, towards the interior, it has since 1846 been connected by railway. In 1768 Spanish Town was made the capital, but in 1872 the seat of Government was removed to Kingston. Kingston was visited in 1880 by a violent hurricane, and by a vast configuration in December 1892, as also before in 1782 and 1848. The most interesting public building was the old church, where Benbow, the "old sea-dog," is buried.

div.head: CAPE TO CAIRO.
div.p: A LADY'S JOURNEY

Rarely has the theatre at Barlington-gardens been more crowded than it was the other afternoon, when Miss Mary Hall delivered a Christmas lecture to the members of the Royal Geographical Society by describing "A Lady's Journey from the Cape to Cairo." The president, Sir George Tanbman Goldie, occupied the chair, and in introducing the lecturer explained that she had traversed the African Continent in its entire length from south to north. From the Cape to the Zambesi in the first place, and from Khartoum to Cairo in the second place, Miss Hall came within the limits of what might be called present-day civilization. Between the Zambebi and Khartoum was the more adventurous part of Africa, and, knowing what Miss Hall had accomplished, he could assert that he had performed a journey of a remarkable character, and one requiring an extraordinary exhibition of courage and capacity, endurance and energy, and, above all, management and tact. Alone and unprotected, she travelled 4,000 miles without a serious bitch. Miss Hall then told the story of her Journey in language well within the comprehension of her audience, a majority of whom were children, who were simply delighted with the snapshots by which the lecture was liberally illustrated. When the natives at Lake Nyanga heard that she was "not married," and had "merely come for a walk," they were amazed and thought "she must be a lunatic." She visited Ujiji, the place where Livingstone labored, and took a photograph of the stone erected to the memory of the great missionary's wife. It was at Ujij: that Stanley met "Dr. Livingstone, I believe ?" At Victoria Nyanza Miss Hall was the first white woman the natives had ever seen in European dress. At Movenga she made a short stay with Bishop Tacker, and caught the young King of Uganda in the thick of a football match. His Majesty was dressed in an appropriate athletic costume, and spoke very fair English. A snapshot was shown of Fashoda, the scene of the celebrated interview between General Kitchener and Colonel Marchand. "My last picture," remarked Miss Hill, is a photograph of the magnificent palace at Khartoum, which has been erected over the site of the former and less assuming residence of the great soldier, General Gordon." At the instance of Sir George Taubman Goldie, thanks were voted to Miss Hall by acclamation.

div.head: CARRIAGES IN EGYPT.
div.p: ENGLISH V. FRENCH.
LONDON MANUFACTURERS' EMPHATIC REJOINDER.

The statement recently appearing in the Journal of the British Chamber of Commerce of Egypt to the effect that French carriages are superior to those made in Great Britain has been promptly challenged by leading carriage builders in London.
Speaking from an experience of more than 40 years, Mr. William Thorp, of the firm of W. and P. Thorn, of Great Portland St., told the "Standard" representative :

"Such a statement amounts to nonsense. The English carriage is far better built, far more serviceable, and of far better value for the money than the French article. It may be a little more expensive, but then you must remember that wages are on a much lower scale in France, and there is no limit to the hours of labour, as in England. Where the French type is different from ours is in the interior elaboration. The French woman is very particular about little fooleries in the way of dainty decorations, and the French carriage builder is bound to study her whims. We could fit up a carriage in every way equal to the French ones, but it would lie on our hands for years before we could sell it to an English customer."

Mr. George H. Thrapp, of the firm of Thropp and Maberly, coach builders to the King, waa even more emphatic. "I was," he said, "one of the official judges at the Chicago Exposition of 1893, and have acted in a similar capacity at most English and foreign exhibitions of recent years, and have never yet seen a French-built carriage that could be placed, for intrinsic merit, side by side with an English vehicle of the game shape. I attribute the increasing popularity of French manufactured conveyances in Egypt to the national proclivities of the middleman there. It is, obviously, his duty to encourage French enterprise, but, from a financial point of view, he would meet with equal encouragement from British manufacturers, and, at the same time, give his clients greater satisfaction."

Mr. Torapp dealt at length with the subject of the exterior appearance of a carriage. With Mr. Thorn, he agrees that the French upholsterer paid more attention to appearances than claimed that in this respect the Parisian manufacturer has bad natural advantages we do not possess. For instance, he worked in a climate which led itself to the art of varnishing, an art that could never be successfully practised in England. Some years ago a British firm arranged with a French concern to engage some of their varnishers, in order to keep the English system could be improved upon. The men brought their own material and their own tools, but the work they turned out was in no way superior to that executed by English workmen.

The manager of the Victoria Carriage Works, in Long-acre, said :-"I think that although in the past the French carriages may have been rather ahead of the English production in the points of luxury and comfort, that superiority no longer exists, as the English manufacturers, for some time past, have recognised that they most excel in this direction as on the point of durability. In my opinion the reason why the French carriage has hitherto been more popular in Egypt is that the French manufacturer has taken more trouble to cultivate the Egyptian market; and it is only quite recently that the English carriage builder has recognised the importance of the Egyptian market for his productions. I am fully convinced that when the English built carriage becomes better known in Egypt it will take the position its intrinsic merit deserves ."

It was left to Mr. Ernest, Windower (Messere. C. S. Windover and Co, Limited) to adopt the most optimistic view of the matter. There is absolutely no foundation for the statement," he said. "We are sending more carriages to Egypt and other parts of the world than we have ever done. That (pointing to an elegant Victoria phaeton) is one of the reasons. If you were to ask me to explain this assertion, I would answer that it is a Parisian model, Not that I consider that it is any better than the English model ; but, just in exactly the same way that an English woman takes her fashions in millinery or in robes from Paris, or Berlin, or Vienna, so she can, if she wishes, have her carriage bolstered to her taste. It is, purely and simply, a case of demand and supply. An English firm can build a far more serviceable vehicle than any French manufacturer ; but if it comes to taste, well, that taste has to be met, and we are quite capable of meeting it."

It is alleged by the "Journal" that the heavy charges made by English firms for packing and carriage have much to do with the falling-off in trade with England. It is stated that the English average costs in freight from 33 to 86 percent on the invoice price, while the French costs only from 13 to 17 per cent. To this Mr. Windover replied in terms of emphatic denial. "We can ship," he said, "a carriage from here to Cairo at a cheaper rate than it would cost to get one from Paris to Alexandria. We only charge the prime cost on freight and insurance, and, so far from it costing 33 per cent., I would guarantee to deliver a phaeton in Cairo-- phaeton costing, say, 150 guiness - for £15. For the same money I would undertake to land a similar vehicle in Bombay."

div.head: PROTRACTED DROUGHT.
div.p: The winter is, perhaps, unprecedented in the meteorological annals of Syria. So far we have bad, indeed, practically no winter. The thermometer from early December till now, the 9th of January, has been ranging between 17 and 19 degrees Centigrade; and Sapnin, which used to put on its robe of ermine white sometimes at the end of November, looks strangely bare and sad now with its thin streaks of white. This long spell of warm and dry weather in the very middle of the rainy season cannot fail to have serious consequences, and perhaps fatal ones if it is farther protracted. Grain crops may receive no damage if a timely shower, at the beginning and end of spring, comes to refresh the tender plants that require only a superficial watering ; but the trees, whose roots lie deep in the earth, will undoubtedly suffer. So far we have had only about 10 inches of rain, and our normal land necessary rainfall should average 30 or 35 inches. Even if the balance of this average is eventually realized the rain will fall short of the desired effect, coming as it will out of season. The olive crop alternation Syria with a defective and plentiful yield, and this year was to be the plentiful one, but owing to the protracted drought it is feared that it will come much short of sanguine anticipations. lndeed, men of experience, but of a pessimistic turn of mood, dread an invasion of locusts, a plague that usually comes as an aggravation of general evils.

div.head: The Austrian Lloyd.
div.p: The Austrian Lloyd Steam Navigation Company is awakening to the commercial spirit of the age. While retaining in its fundamental form the old régime of "agences de carrière," and thus enjoying while submitting to the Government patronage, the company is trying to develop the commercial side on purely commercial and to a certain extent independent lines. The principal agency at Beyrout, which so far has been an agence de carrière, is to be soon transformed into an agency on the basis of commission, just as that of a company of cargo steamers. The practicability of the English system by which an agent may exponentially increase his income only by increasing pro rata the earnings of the company be represented, is beginning to be realized on the Continent. And the credit for the company's latest step is due mainly to the bold initiative of the general manager of the Austrian Lloyd, and to the same power of government in him which led the managing director of the Prince Line to change as representative the very same man who by his honesty, capacity, zeal, and tout has so much contributed to consolidate the position of that line in these waters. I mean Mr. Othon G Tattarachi. In choosing a Greek gentleman for agent the general manager of the Maatrian Lloyd has boldly overruled the prejudice of nationality, which in some quarters is yet insisted upon rather narrowly, regardless of merit.

div.head: Social Functions,
div.p: The season's gates were inaugurated by a bright Christmas "reveillon" given to a party of friends at the mansion of Muzaffer Pasba, Governor General of Lebanon. Although there may be some doubts as to their administrative capacity and worth-and I use this collective term for those who can read between the lines-no one can deny that for successful social reception, the Miz offers are not easily surpassed. Cordiality and gracionazes of manner, that is so well calculated to create that homely feeling, and a well ordered generosity, mark their receptions. A rich and dainty cold copper was served followed by a little unconventional dancing, and, at last, thoughtfully chosen souvenirs were distributed amongst the "convives." .

Mr. George Covillon, the energetic and intelligent director of the gas works, and his distinguished looking and spirituelle wife invited the same party, and some other friend besides, to a similar evening on Epiphany, It was admittedly the gayest and freest of functions. Most of the French colony were there, and the gracious presence of Sir Robert and Lady Drummond-Hay was a proof of the sincerity and adding character of the entente between the two greatest neighbouring nations, The beautiful house of the Covillons, perched or a projecting cliff, and surrounded by a covered verandah facing the sea, looked, with its profusion of gas lights, particularly charming. Light dancing alterosted with monologues reclaimed by Vice-Conel Mr. F. Wiet, and Dr. Chapo'in, of the French Medical Faculty. Mme Noblet and Mme Dr. Astar looked particularly elegant and pretty amongst the younger set. Mme Noblet recited a monologue with creditable nerve and delicacy of rendering. A copious "diner froid" was served after midnight, and the famous old wines of the Covillons and their good champagne contributed to raise to a pitch the general hilarity.

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondants, but we wish, in the spirit of fair play to all, to permit-within certain necessary limits free discussion.
M.P.'S IN EGYPT
To the EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Sir,- In view of the mischievous, policy of some Members of Parliament in regard to Egypt would it not be advisable for us to follow the excellent principle laid down by the Romans in regard to Egypt and forbid all such gentry setting foot in the country. When Egypt was incorporated into the Roman Empire it was most wisely ordained that the Senate as such, as well as every individual of its members, should on no account be allowed to meddle with the affairs of the country. They were catted off from all participation in its government. In fact, senators and persons of senatorial rank were even prohibited from getting foot in this province. The motives which induced Augustus at the very outset of his sole rale to adopt this wise regulation are obvious; and it is worth noting that the arrangement was at no time assailed, for its policy was fully understood. However, although the Capitulations prevent Egypt from making any such law, would it not be feasible for the British Parliament to pass it, for the type of Padgett, M P., is no longer a humorous class of person; he is becoming a menace to the Empire. Sir Siward Grey, who is as good an Imperialist as were his immediate conservative predeces, Lord Lansdowne and Lord Salisbury, might be induced to consider the advisability of some such measure.--I am, etc.
S. P. C. A.
To the Editor of the "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE" |

Dear Sir,--Fortunately the nature of the average Englishman precludes him from the pastime of throwing bouquets at himself, as I once heard an American designate the set of self-praise. Therefore, on reading the annual report of the Ghirga brand of the above society which appeared in your of the 9th inst., I came to the conclusion it had been supplied by the local hon sec., his name being entirely omitted therefrom.

Assuming this to be the case, it is a pleasure: to record an appreciation of the whole-hearted and energetic efforts of Mr. Hartsbourne, the agent of the Agricultural Bank, in that capacity. There must be a quiet satisfaction derived from work of this nature which no self advertisement could enhance.

In the report it is declared that the native notables have shown no notice interest in the operation of the society. That they have liberally responded to appeals for financial assistance is evident from the satisfactory balance in hand, which should enable the committee to realize its projects for the future.
This is not the only district in which the agents of the Agricultural Bank have identified themselves with the S.P.C.A. More power to them.-Yours faithfully,

div.head: EDUCATION IN EGYPT
div.p: MR. WELLS'S VIEWS.
(FROM THE "MORNING POST").

Mr. Sidney H. Wells, Principal of the Batteries Polytechnic, has undertaken the reorganisation of secondary and technical education in Egypt, and in the course of the next few months that highly successful institution in Battersea Park-road will lose the services of one who since its very beginning 14 years ago next June, has played a great part in its wonderful progress. "We are one of the best known and are doing the biggest work of any such institutions in the country; our income last year was nearly twenty five thousand pounds ; we have enlarged our buildings five times; we are not a penny in debt and we are still growing," remarked Mr. Well to a representative of the "Morning Post". Not only will he leave behind him a splendid work at the Polytechnic, but he is associated with many other spheres of active usefulness. He is a member of the Consultative Committee of the Board of Education, the Teacher Registration Council, the secretary and a member of the Faculty of Engineering of London University, having been one of the original members to be appointed by the University Commissioners, and he is also a member and former secretary of the Board of Studies in Civil and Mechanical Engineering He is a member of the City and Guild Nominations Board as a representative of the Board of Education; a member of the Joint Scholarship Board and former chairman of its intermediate Scholarships Committee; bop. secretary of the Association of Technical institutions, of the Council of which he has been a member for eight years; a member of the Council and Executive of the National Union of Training Schools of Domestic science, and chairman of its Examination, Sub-Committee; and as a representative of the London City Council be in a member of the governing body of the Sir Walter St. John's Schools, Batteries. In addition he is a member of the Council of the Incorporated 'Association of Head Masters, and for the year 1906 was chairman of the London Division of the Association. Naturally the parting of the ways in a case like this will cause many regrets; but, as Mr. Wells said: "am fascinated by the problem in Egypt, by the interest that is taken in the whole question by the people, by the earnest desire of Lord Cromer and other important officials to do their best for the technical education of the natives, and by the enormous problems which around the particular piece of work that lies before one." It was just prior to coming home last summer that Lord Cromer's attention seemed to have been drawn especially to the need for the development of technical education in Egypt, and as the result of consultations with those at home interested in the subject Mr. Wells was asked by Lord Croner and the Egyptian Government if he would come to see what was being done, and present a report and scheme for the whole of the country. Mr. Wells came out in October, and during the three and a half weeks he was here he went everywhere where anything had been done or where anything was contemplated.
GENERAL EDUCATION IN VOGUE.

Asked for an idea of the impressions he gained, Mr. Wells gave a most interesting review, beginning first with the village schools, which are known as Kuttaks, he said, "are of various grades, from tiny dirty rooms with five or six boy and girls, under a native teacher, learning to read the Koran, up to schools of five rooms with teachers partly trained to take a more regular course. ln the Kuttabs, which are to be found all over the country, the teaching is entirely in Arabic, and the work may be said to be confined to reading, writing, and the elements of arithmetic. Next are what are called the primary schools, which correspond to some extent to our elementary schools, both as regards the aim and scope of the work. Some of the Kuttabs are aided by the Government, but the primary schools are all under Government direction, built and Maintained by the Government, and into the curriculum includes the teaching of English and in some cases French. They Have a four year course, and at the end of it the boys take an examination to obtain what is called a primary school certificate. The course is much like our own, English being thoroughly well taught, also French if desired; science is being introduced and generally the curriculum is a good literary course.Most of the headmasters and many of the staff are English, but in one case at least there is a native headmaster with English assistants. The course is also one of four years, at the end of which time an examination for a farther certificate is passed qualifying for intermediate positions in the Government service or for admission to the higher colleges, of which there are three, all in Cairo-the Polytechnic (the work of which is at present confined to preparing engineers for the Irrigation Service), the School of Medicine, and the School of Law. The staff of the Polytechnic and of the School of Medicine are almost entirely English ; the head of the School of Law is a Frenchman, and there are French professors in the other institutions. There is also a school of Agriculture and Engineering and Technical School of the intermediate grade open to boys who have passed through the primary school."
TRADE SCHOOLS.

"The chief work in technical education lies in the direction of what we should call trade schools. In Egypt they go under various names, such as model workshops and technical school. They take the boys from the Kattabs and train them to be good craftsmen and artisans. Engineering is the chief industry for which they are prepared ; the building trades come next, especially woodworking. Some do leather work and saddlery, one or two printing and weaving, and one or two conduct departments in musbrabbia and inlaid work. One school, known as the Model Workshops, situated at Boulao, a suburb of Cairo, has 300 pupils, and it is doing excellent work. Then there is the Customs Porters' School at Alexandria, which is now being moved to large new buildings erected by one of the Mohammedan societies interested in education. When completed it will accommodate 450 or 500 boys. At Mansurah there is a school chiefly for wood-working; Assiout, a ten hour railway journey from Cairo, has a model workshop; and, added Mr. Wells, there is a very interesting small technical school still further apart from the country at Abu Tig. This has been founded by one of the wealthy Pashar, who is a Vice President of the Legislative Council, and who has built and maintains the school. It is worked entirely by native teachers, and the trades taught include woodworking, smiths' work, weaving, and inlaid and mushrabia work. A characteristic feature of these trade schools is that they do work for outside orders, charging as far as possible market prices. ""In This way," remarked Mr. Wells, "they secure a variety of work which would otherwise not be possible. Generally speaking, the lade also receive a certain amount of instruction in continuation of their general education--reading, writing, and arithmetic.--and elementary lessons on the technical side of their trades. This type of school is very largely needed in the Country and the people are much interested in their development. In Beni Suef and Fayoum, two districts in Upper Egypt, the wealthy landowners, at the suggestion of the moudir of the province, have collected over £10,000 for building a technical school and have contributed Land to endow it. With some of the English officials I attended a meeting of these landowners, and I couldn't help noticing how keenly interested they were. A similar scheme is being projected at Damanboor at the suggestion of Prince Haegein. The Coptic Societies have built two technical schools, one a very large building not yet completed, and in addition several of the other European nation cities, the French, the Greeks, and the Italians have their own technical schools; indeed, they have their own general school, primary and secondary, and together with such bodies as the American Mission are doing a great work to help in the education of the native."
URGENT NEEDS.

"It is in the extension of this type of school that the first development of technical education appears to be called for. Among other things there is need for further instruction in such schools in the building trades, particularly for plumbers and plasterers. The most likely development in this class of institution is a school or schools for the building trades, for electrical work, and for artistic crafts, particularly with a view to developing the native industries of Egypt. There is a call for some training in electrical work in view of the extension of electric lighting in the large towns. This type of intermediate school will further aim at preparing the foremen, clerks of works, draughtsman, designers, etc. , and its students should have been through the primary school, while all its instruction would be in English. I hope that some central institution of that character may be possible in Cairo within the next few years, and as the movement develops possibly in Alexandria as well. With regard to the higher type of technical work, the field at present is somewhat limited. There is an increasing demand for engineers in the Irrigation Service. There is also a need for trained men in the Public Buildings Department and in the Survey Department. My hope is that the Polytechnic may before long develop departments to train men for such work, and that it may also arrange courses for the higher training of mechanical and electrical engineers. It should be pointed out that, as Egypt is essentially an agricultural country depending for its prosperity upon its agricultural products, practically all the technical education in the country arises from agricultural needs. For example, engineers are wanted because pumping machinery, steam engines, steam plough, and other agricultural machinery are now replacing the older methods of manual labor ; wood-workers are wanted because carts are being used for agricultural purposes, and harness is required for the horses. So that really the whole thing depends on the needs of agriculture. It is for this reason that the new Department which has just been formed as the result of one of my recommendations has been termed the Department of Agriculture and Technical Education, following, indeed, the well known example of the department which exists in Ireland."
SUGGESTIONS ACCEPTED.

"As I said, I was first out there for over three weeks. I saw what was being done and came in contact with many people. But I could not stay to finish my work because of engagements at home. I went out again during the Christmas vacation, taking my report, and then finishing my inquiries into some sections of the work which I was not able to complete during my first visit. After consideration of my report Lord Cromer and the Government decided to accept generally the suggestions made and to create a new Department attached to the Ministry of Education, the position of Director General. I have accepted the appointment, but I do not expect to formally commence until October, I hope, however, to be able to go out for a month in April or May in order to prepare the way for future work. I am attracted by the immense possibilities of the country. The people have every confidence in Lord Cromer, who has done magnificent work. He is intensely interested in the whole movement, and so are the Minister of Education and the Educational Advisor, Mr. Dunlop."
WOMEN'S EDUCATION.

The question of the education of women in Egypt has received the consideration of Mr. Wells. "Up to the present," he said, "there has been practically nothing done in the way of technical education for women, except that which has just been commenced in the Girls' Secondary School and in one of the schools for training women teachers for the Kattabs. My own hope is that we may be able to do something for women in private schools of domestic economy, where they will be taught to manage their own homes on better lines and also receive instruction in what they very much need, the care and bringing up of infants, so that the present infant mortality may be reduced. Also, I think, there is a promising field in aging the skill of the native women in art needlework, for which they seem to be specially qualified. But this will be a work of time, and it will require a very great deal of care owing to the position of women in Egypt. A good deal of sympathy has been shown with the isles of doing some work of this kind. Lord Cromer himself is most anxious that something should be done for the women when it can be wisely done, and their side certainly will not be overlooked as far as I am concerned."

div.head: DELAYS AT GENOA PORT.
div.p: At a meeting of the Newcastle and Gates head Chamber of Commerce last week a letter was read from Sir Edward Grey stating that the Foreign Office had taken steps in the matter of the delays at the Port of Genoa. It appeared that the Italian Government were fully alive to the gravity of the situation caused by the delay, and were endeavouring to ameliorate them. They were constructing along the line from Genoa to Milan numerous bindings, the absence of which had caused delay by preventing the railway authorities at time from employing all the goods track, available.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: Captain and Brevet Major G. B. Macauley, Royal Engineers, manager of the Egyptian State Railways, has been placed on half pay under the provisions of Article 92s, Royal Warrant, 1906.

Captain R. G. Stracey, 1st Battalion Soots Guards, has been selected for employment with the Khedive's troops, and will join immediately at Cairo. This officer has been connected with the Guards since August, 1900, and had some experience in campaigning in the South African War, 1902, including the operations in the Transvaal (Queen's medal with four clasps).

Commander A. G. Hotham and Commander J. E. T. Harper, on promotion, have been re-appointed to the battleship Queen and the cruiser Bacchante, on the Mediterranean Station, respectively, for navigation duties.

The country is still waiting on Mr. Haldane's ideal scheme which is to give us "a nation in arms." The return of recruiting for the past year, just published, shows that 36,465 men were enlisted, but opposed to this was a wastage of 46,414-a difference of 10,000 men on the wrong side of the book. This is a small army, from England's standpoint, in itself. The deficiency, of course, can be accounted for to the satisfaction of those who care to wade amongst the figures, but with such talk of economy with efficiency in the air, the whole position is very far from being satisfactory. What Mr. Haldane intends to take the place of our vanishing army he has not yet made quite clear--perhaps not to himself. He has reduced the army without doing anything to increase its efficiency in any one way, and he has earned for himself the reputation of being a first class windbag in the Cabinet of Government where that particular genus is well and ably represented. He is still "considering problems," still telling us what he intends to do, And after twelve months he has achieved nothing but destruction.

It is understood the various regiments of Royal Garrison Artillery Militia will train as usual in the coming drill season, but for the limited period of 21 days. Mr. Haldane's held batteries of Militia seems a long way off yet.

div.head: Severe Canadian Winters Deprived of their Danger
div.p: Colds and Their After-Effects Conquered By the Use of Pe-ru-na.
Mayor of Scotstown Recommends Pe-ru-na for Colds and Catarrh.
Read his letter.
The first effect of a cold is a thickening of the mucous membranes of the nose and throat.
This gives rise to a discharge, or at least a stillness of the nasal passages.
Sometimes fever accompanies the first attack, also a feeling of languor, dullness and aching of the bones.
If no attention is paid to it, the mucous congestion is liable to spread down into the larynx, producing hoarseness and into the bronchial tube producing a cough.
Even when this occurs, many people pay no attention to it.
Under such circumstances, the congestion is liable to become chronic, producing a condition of the mucous membranes known as catarrh. Catarrh lasts an indefinite time.
CURE COLDS -- PREVENTS CATARRH
Catarrh is essentially a chronic condition and does not leave except something is done to relieve it.
What should be done when a person catches a cold is to take a few doses of Peruna.
Taken at the onset, Peruna would break up the cold and prevent all the train of symptoms which usually follow.
But, even in cases where the cold has been neglected and hoarseness or a cough has developed, Peruna can be relied upon to give prompt and permanent relief.
The frequency of coughs and colds in Canada makes Peruna a popular remedy in this country.
A number of the best people in Canada have given testimonials as to the value of Perana in such cases.
Followed Dr. Hartman's Advice Restored to Health.
Mrs. Samuelle Vigneau, Avre au Berd, Isle de La Magdaline, Canada, writes.
"I write to tell you that I am perfectly well. I took only three bottles of your Peruna according to your advice and the directions in your book and it restored my health."

C.H. Parker, Ex-Warden of Compton Co. Quebec writes, "I had several attacks of colds from time to time and finally a severe attack developed into catarrh. I was advised to use your celebrated remedy and after taking three bottles I find myself completley cured and I no longer suffer from cattarh or colds."
Should you desire special instructions relative to the use of Peruna, address Dr S.B. Hartman, President of the Hartman Sanitarium, Columbus, Ohio.
All correspondence held strictly confidential:

For special directions everyone should read "The Ills of Life," a copy of which surrounds each bottle. Peruna is for sale by all chemists and druggists at five shillings per bottle or six bottles for twenty-five shillings. Those wishing direct correspondence with Dr. Hartman and can wait the necessary delay in receiving a reply should address Dr. S.B. Hartman, Columbus, Ohio, U.S.A.

Dans son numéro d'hier, le "Journal Officiel" publie le décret khédivial, l'acte préliminaire d'association et les gtatota d'ane Société anoNyme formée au Caire P006 la dénomination de "The Egyptian Economic R sidence," ad capital de LE 100,000 représenté par 25,000 actions de LB 4 chaconne.

L'objet de la nouvelle Société est de mettre la disposition des populations urbaines d'Egypte des habitations à bon marché. LA *!& tôt, nous apprennent q7e cette revivre humanitaire sera étendue au Soudan, simon plas avant vers le Sad.

Parmi les premiers administrateurs (qui sont précisément les sept fondateurs de la 80 ciété, sane angade exclusion) figurent MY Pal Ozo', Joseph Jabee, H. Camel Toueg et. questre autres grandes à mes charitables restée. modestement jusqu'ici dans l'ombre.

Le chapitre le plus intéressant des state est celui qui se rapporte au partage des profits. Après les prélèvements statutaires ordinaire', l'excédent des bénéfices sera 1er parti à raison de 75 o/sox actionnaire et de 25 olo (vingt-cinq pour cent également aux admi. nistration.......

Nous avons annoncé, en dernière beure, dans notre Circulaire de samedi passé, que l'assemblée générale statutaire de l'Epargne Immobilière Ltd., tende ce même foar du Caire, avait approuvé à l'unanimité la proposition du Conseil d'administration tendant à porter le capital social de £100,000 & 800,000 bar la création de 175,000 actions nouvelles de fa chaoune. W assemblée a eu même temps donne au conseil les pouvoirs les plus étendus pour le placement de ces nouvelles actions.

Des renseignements communiqués par le conseil il résulte que la Société à déjà conclu de très Belles affaires. Elle a notamment acheté, dans des conditions exceptionnellement davantage ases, environ 80,000 mètres de terrains sis à la pointe de Gh-zireb au Caire, terrains qui sont revendus avec de grandes facilités. la Société tirera un bénéfice d'environ 150,000 livres de cette revente qui promet. d'être achevée en deux pois,
La Société a fait d'autres achats à d'excellentes conditions. Comme ces terrains sont payés en actions, que bonne partie des nouvelles actions se trouve déjà placée de cette façon.

Oo fait courir en Bourse la rumeur que la fusion serait à peu près complétée entre les National Hotels et l'Anglo-Egyptian Hotels Co. Cette dernière Société serait constitués en capital de £1,500,000 en actions de £l avec 20,000 parts de fondateur.

L'échange des actions et parts de fondateur se ferait de la manière suivante : on donnerait 4 actions de la Société anglaise pour chaque action des National Hotel et une part de fondateur de la nouvelle Compagnie pour 101 parts National Hotela.

Les parts de fondateur National Hotels seraient spécialement avantagées par cette comme pupaison gråe à laquelle elles prendraient le quart des parte do fondateur de la nouvelle Société, c'est à dire qu'elles participent dans une proportion double du capital.
